alert.note: Alert for Los Angeles (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 04 at 3:44PM PDT by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 645 PM PDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by heavy rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of southwest California, including the mountains in Los Angeles and Ventura counties, as well as the western portion of the Antelope Valley. Thunderstorm activity is expected to expand across the Ventura county mountains this afternoon. * WHEN...Until 645 PM PDT. * IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall could trigger urban and small stream flooding as well as shallow debris flows in and near recent wildfire burn scars. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 336 PM PDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms, with estimated rainfall rates between 0.5 and 1.0 inch per hour in heavier thunderstorms. Roadway and small stream flooding is expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. - Some locations that could experience flooding include... Santa Clarita, Palmdale, Lockwood Valley, Rose Valley, Sylmar, Pyramid Lake, Alamo Mountain, Interstate 5 over the Grapevine, Topatopa Peak, , Gorman, Frazier Mountain, Castaic Lake, Highway 138 between Quail Lake and Lancaster, Highway 33 between Wheeler Springs and Rose Valley Road, Reyes Peak and Highway 33 from Lockwood Valley Road to the Santa Barbara County line. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Move away from recently burned areas. The rain will likely trigger shallow mud and debris flows, minor rock falls, and flooding capable of localized damage, especially in steep terrain in and near burn scars. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
